questions.question: What manages program execution order?
questions.explanation: Process scheduler determines program execution order. Algorithms: FCFS, round-robin, priority-based. Context switch: pause one, run another. Fairness: all processes get time. Responsiveness: interactive feel. Efficiency: maximize CPU utilization. Starvation: prevent process indefinitely waiting.

questions.question: What coordinates CPU and I/O?
questions.explanation: Chipset coordinates CPU-memory-I/O communication. Components: northbridge (high-speed), southbridge (I/O). PCH (Platform Controller Hub): modern term. Buses: connect components. Bottleneck: can limit throughput. Upgrade: limited individual component. Design: determines capabilities.

questions.question: What allows component expansion?
questions.explanation: Expansion slots allow adding components. Standard: PCIe (PCI Express). Examples: graphics cards, network cards, storage controllers. Speed: generations (PCIe 3.0, 4.0, 5.0). Backward compatible: older cards work. Resource: IRQ, DMA allocation. Benefits: upgrade capability.

questions.question: What manages memory access?
questions.explanation: Memory controller manages RAM access. Timing: coordinates reads/writes. Refresh: DRAM periodically refreshed. ECC: error correction (if supported). Speed: matches CPU/motherboard. Performance: impacts latency. Location: typically on CPU (modern).

questions.question: What handles multiple displays?
questions.explanation: Graphics card renders visual output. Memory: VRAM (video RAM) for image data. Performance: measured TFLOPS (trillion floating point operations). Cooling: GPU generates heat. Driver: software enables functionality. Gaming: high-end cards for performance. Edit: professional cards for accuracy.

questions.question: What provides wireless connectivity?
questions.explanation: Network adapter connects to network. Types: Ethernet (wired), WiFi (wireless). Speed: measured Mbps (megabits/second). Driver: OS software controls. Configuration: IP address, DNS. Multiple: simultaneous connections possible. Quality: signal strength varies.

questions.question: What converts analog to digital?
questions.explanation: Sound card handles audio I/O. Functions: input (microphone), output (speakers). DAC: converts digital to analog. ADC: converts analog to digital. Quality: sampling rate (Hz), bit depth (bits). Latency: delay introduced. Professional: studio-grade cards available.

questions.question: What manages data transfer speed?
questions.explanation: Bus speed determines data transfer rate. Measured: MHz or GHz. Types: system bus, address bus, data bus. Bandwidth: total data per second. Bottleneck: limits maximum throughput. Upgrade: affects system performance. Modern: very high speeds (PCIe 4.0+).

questions.question: What provides power distribution?
questions.explanation: Power distribution provides stable voltage. VRM: regulates CPU/component voltage. Ripple: noise in power signal. Quality: affects stability, overclocking. Failure: system instability, crashes. Capacitors: store/release energy. Modern: multi-phase for precision.

questions.question: What enables data persistence?
questions.explanation: Firmware initializes hardware on boot. BIOS: legacy 16-bit (limited). UEFI: modern 32/64-bit (enhanced). Functions: hardware detection, boot loader start. Updates: manufacturer releases patches. Security: protects against attacks. Settings: CPU voltage, fan speed customization.
